headline:
Benchmarking learner-centric higher education institutions
					How well do four-year US colleges and universities serve different segments of learners across the student life cycle? Explore this interactive.
					Interactive

.carousel {
  position: relative;
  margin-bottom: 20px;
  line-height: 1;
}

.carousel-inner {
  position: relative;
  width: 100%;
  overflow: hidden;
}

.carousel-inner > .item {
  position: relative;
  display: none;
  -webkit-transition: 0.6s ease-in-out left;
     -moz-transition: 0.6s ease-in-out left;
       -o-transition: 0.6s ease-in-out left;
          transition: 0.6s ease-in-out left;
}

.carousel-inner > .item > img,
.carousel-inner > .item > a > img {
  display: block;
  line-height: 1;
}

.carousel-inner > .active,
.carousel-inner > .next,
.carousel-inner > .prev {
  display: block;
}

.carousel-inner > .active {
  left: 0;
}

.carousel-inner > .next,
.carousel-inner > .prev {
  position: absolute;
  top: 0;
  width: 100%;
}

.carousel-inner > .next {
  left: 100%;
}

.carousel-inner > .prev {
  left: -100%;
}

.carousel-inner > .next.left,
.carousel-inner > .prev.right {
  left: 0;
}

.carousel-inner > .active.left {
  left: -100%;
}

.carousel-inner > .active.right {
  left: 100%;
}

.carousel-control {
  position: absolute;
  top: 40%;
  left: 15px;
  width: 40px;
  height: 40px;
  margin-top: -20px;
  font-size: 60px;
  font-weight: 100;
  line-height: 30px;
  color: #ffffff;
  text-align: center;
  background: #222222;
  border: 3px solid #ffffff;
  -webkit-border-radius: 23px;
     -moz-border-radius: 23px;
          border-radius: 23px;
  opacity: 0.5;
  filter: alpha(opacity=50);
}

.carousel-control.right {
  right: 15px;
  left: auto;
}

.carousel-control:hover,
.carousel-control:focus {
  color: #ffffff;
  text-decoration: none;
  opacity: 0.9;
  filter: alpha(opacity=90);
}

.carousel-indicators {
  position: absolute;
  top: 15px;
  right: 15px;
  z-index: 5;
  margin: 0;
  list-style: none;
}

.carousel-indicators li {
  display: block;
  float: left;
  width: 10px;
  height: 10px;
  margin-left: 5px;
  text-indent: -999px;
  background-color: #ccc;
  background-color: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0.25);
  border-radius: 5px;
}

.carousel-indicators .active {
  background-color: #fff;
}

.carousel-caption {
  position: absolute;
  right: 0;
  bottom: 0;
  left: 0;
  padding: 15px;
  background: #333333;
  background: rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.75);
}

.carousel-caption h4,
.carousel-caption p {
  line-height: 20px;
  color: #ffffff;
}

.carousel-caption h4 {
  margin: 0 0 5px;
}

.carousel-caption p {
  margin-bottom: 0;
}
</style>

                                                <h1 class="banner-heading fadeIn animated slower col-md-10 text-white font-48 lh-1 font-weight-light" id="bannerHeading" data-id="1">
                                                    Student success benchmarking in higher education
                                                </h1>
                                                <h2 class="banner-subheading fadeIn animated slower col-md-10 text-white font-30 lh-1 font-weight-600 mt-xl-4 mt-0 mb-xl-0 mb-4" id="bannersubHead" data-id="1">
                                                    Evaluating institutional performance across learner segments 
                                                </h2>

With the learning needs of many college students changing, how well do US colleges and universities serve different learner segments—in college and beyond?

            </section>
            <!-- Content highlight area end here -->

            <!-- load more content section start here-->
            <section name="Article" id="load-more-content">
                <div class="container">
                    <div class="row justify-content-center">
                        <!-- Quote 1 start here -->
                        <div class="col-12 col-md-9">
                            <div class="row justify-content-center mx-auto">
                                <div class="col-12 col-md-11 mx-auto">
                                    <p class="font-16 font-weight-regular introSubHeading" style="padding-bottom: 0.875rem">
                                        In recent years, the profile of incoming US college students has changed dramatically. No longer does the typical student come to college straight from high school,
                                        attend classes full-time, and live on campus.
                                    </p>
                                    <p class="font-16 font-weight-regular introSubHeading" style="padding-bottom: 0.875rem">
                                        At last count, nearly a third of college students were 25 years or older, 39% attended class part-time, and over 40% were from communities of color.<a class="blue-text" tabindex="0" aria-label="endnote1" id="endnotes-1" onclick="scrollToBottom(event);"><sup>1</sup></a>
                                        Moreover, 43% of full-time undergraduates work<a class="blue-text" tabindex="0" aria-label="endnote2" id="endnotes-2" onclick="scrollToBottom(event);"><sup>2</sup></a>, 22% of all undergraduates have children<a class="blue-text" tabindex="0" aria-label="endnote3" id="endnotes-3" onclick="scrollToBottom(event);"><sup>3</sup></a>, and 56% are the first in their families to attend college.<a class="blue-text" tabindex="0" aria-label="endnote4" id="endnotes-4" onclick="scrollToBottom(event);"><sup>4</sup></a>
                                    </p>
                                    <p class="font-16 font-weight-regular introSubHeading" style="padding-bottom: 0.875rem">
                                        With such diversity, the decades-old lens through which higher education institutions typically view students—either “traditional” students entering college after
                                        high school, or “nontraditional” students entering college through other means—ceases to be meaningful. Institutions seeking to improve student outcomes should
                                        understand what motivates different types of learners and tailor their offerings to better meet learners’ unique needs and learning preferences.
                                    </p>
                                    <p class="font-16 font-weight-regular introSubHeading">
                                                                                    This interactive brings together data from multiple sources—<a class="fontNormal ref-link" tabindex="" role="link" aria-label="Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System" target="_blank" href="https://nces.ed.gov/ipeds/">Integrated Postsecondary Education Data System</a>,
                                <a class="fontNormal ref-link" tabindex="" role="link" aria-label="College Scorecard" target="_blank" href="https://collegescorecard.ed.gov/">College Scorecard</a>,
                                <a class="fontNormal ref-link" tabindex="" role="link" aria-label="Income Segregation and Intergenerational Mobility Across Colleges in the United States dataset" target="_blank" href="https://opportunityinsights.org/paper/undermatching/">Income Segregation and Intergenerational Mobility Across Colleges in the United States dataset</a> from Raj Chetty et al.,
                                and
                                <a class="fontNormal ref-link" tabindex="" role="link" aria-label="Georgetown University Center on Education and the Workforce’s College ROI dataset" target="_blank" href="https://cew.georgetown.edu/cew-reports/CollegeROI/">Georgetown University Center on Education and the Workforce’s College ROI dataset</a>—to
                                explore the institutional performance of more than 1,500 four-year colleges and universities across a wide range of student success and equity measures. Institutions can use this interactive benchmarking tool to see how
                                they compare with their Carnegie peers and other similar colleges and universities.
                                <a class="blue-text endNotesSpaceHandler" aria-label="endNotesSpaceHandler" tabindex="0" id="endnotes-5" onclick="scrollToBottom(event);"><sup>5</sup></a>
                            </p>
                                </div>
                            </div>
                        </div>
                        <!-- Quote 1 end here -->
                    </div>
                </div>
                <!-- <div class="watermarkOverlayLeft2"></div> -->
            </section>
            <!-- load more content section end here-->

            <!--Carousal section start here -->
            <section name="Carousel" id="pupose-section-8" class="cgi-spacing-large bg-lightestgrey" style="margin-top: 0rem !important">
                <div class="justify-content-center">
                    <div class="row">
                        <div class="col-12 col-md-12">
                            <div id="stepsSectionCarousel" class="carousel slide" data-interval="false" data-ride="carousel">
                                <div class="carousel-inner" id="fullScreenWrapper">
                                    <div class="carousel-item active bg-circle-img item">
                                        <div class="item cardItem visited" data-id="1">
                                            <div id="page1">
                                                <div class="container">
                                                    <div class="row">
                                                        <div class="col-12 col-md-12 mx-auto spacing cover-content-wrapper" data-sequence="500" data-aos-duration="500">
                                                            <!-- <div id="bg-overlay"></div> -->
                                                            <div class="row font-family-open">
                                                                <div class="col-12 col-md-12 mx-auto div-spacing">
                                                                    <p class="cover-banner-content font-36 font-weight-light">Step 1</p>
                                                                    <h2 class="carousel-heading" data-id="1">SEARCH BY INSTITUTION NAME</h2>
                                                                    <div class="classification-container"></div>
                                                                    <input data-search="" type="text" autocomplete="off" id="stepFirstSearchInput" class="search-option" placeholder="Search by Institution Name" onkeyup="showSearchResult('stepFirstSearchInput', 'slide1-list-wrapper', 'page1')">
                                                                    <ul tabindex="0" id="slide1-list-wrapper" class="list-wrapper"></ul>
                                                                    <span class="errorMsg">This analysis includes all US four-year colleges and universities with an undergraduate enrollment of more than 500 students.
                                                                        Institutions with missing or insufficient data were excluded from this analysis.</span>
                                                                </div>
                                                            </div>
                                                        </div>
                                                    </div>
                                                </div>
                                            </div>
                                        </div>
                                    </div>
                                    <div class="carousel-item bg-circle-img item">
                                        <div class="item cardItem" data-id="1">
                                            <div id="page2">
                                                <!-- #wrapper -->
                                                <div class="container">
                                                    <div class="row font-family-open">
                                                        <div class="col-12 col-md-9 mx-auto div-spacing">
                                                            <p class="cover-banner-content font-36 font-weight-light">Step 2</p>
                                                            <h2 class="carousel-heading" data-id="1">select type of learner</h2>
                                                            <p class="description-content">
                                                                Pearson’s segmentation analysis of the US learner population ages 14–40 years based on learner attitudes about the perceived value of higher
                                                                education, the motivation of current and prospective students, and learning preferences revealed distinct learner segments: traditional
                                                                learners, career learners, reluctant learners, and skeptical learners.
                                                                <a class="blue-text endNotesSpaceHandler" aria-label="endnotes6" id="endnotes-6" tabindex="0" onclick="scrollToBottom(event);"><sup>6</sup></a>
                                                            </p>
                                                        </div>
                                                    </div>
                                                    <div class="row">
                                                        <div class="col-xl-3">
                                                            <div role="button" tabindex="0" class="box-container Traditional">
                                                                <div class="image-container"></div>
                                                                <h4 class="heading text-transform-upper">Traditional learner</h4>
                                                                <p class="description">
                                                                    18–24-year-olds attending brick-and-mortar institutions for the traditional college experience. This segment is less price-sensitive and
                                                                    passionate about learning, and prefers in-person instruction.
                                                                </p>
                                                            </div>
                                                        </div>
                                                        <div class="col-xl-3">
                                                            <div role="button" tabindex="0" class="box-container Career">
                                                                <div class="image-container"></div>
                                                                <h4 class="heading text-transform-upper">Career learner</h4>
                                                                <p class="description">
                                                                    These learners place a high value on education, see college as a stepping stone to professional success, and prefer to learn digitally.
                                                                </p>
                                                            </div>
                                                        </div>
                                                        <div class="col-xl-3">
                                                            <div role="button" tabindex="0" class="box-container Reluctant">
                                                                <div class="image-container"></div>
                                                                <h4 class="heading text-transform-upper">Reluctant learner</h4>
                                                                <p class="description">
                                                                    These students learn because they have to, not because they want to. They favor flexibility and are price-sensitive.
                                                                </p>
                                                            </div>
                                                        </div>
                                                        <div class="col-xl-3">
                                                            <div role="button" tabindex="0" class="box-container Skeptical">
                                                                <div class="image-container"></div>
                                                                <h4 class="heading text-transform-upper">Skeptical learner</h4>
                                                                <p class="description">
                                                                    These learners self-identify as average or below-average students, are very price-sensitive, and favor digital modes of learning over
                                                                    in-person.
                                                                </p>
                                                            </div>
                                                        </div>
                                                        <!-- Definition Step 2 -->
                                                        <div class="col-xl-3 d-xl-none">
                                                            <div data-step="step2" class="definition-container definition">
                                                                <div class="def-img">
                                                                    <img id="figure-03" data-id="3" alt="Definitions" title="Definitions" src="https://www2.deloitte.com/etc/insights-lists/interactives/staging/2021/June/CGI-future-of-higher-education/assets/def-i.svg">
                                                                </div>
                                                                <h4 class="heading text-transform-upper">Definitions</h4>
                                                            </div>
                                                        </div>

                                                <!-- /#wrapper -->
                                            </div>
                                        </div>

                                        <div class="item cardItem" data-id="1">
                                            <div id="page11">

                                                        <div class="col-12 col-md-9 mx-auto div-spacing">
                                                            <p class="cover-banner-content font-36 font-weight-light">Step 3</p>
                                                            <h2 class="carousel-heading" data-id="1">SELECT COMPARISON CATEGORY</h2>
                                                            <p class="description-content">
                                                                Assess how an institution performs relative to its Carnegie peers, to other four-year postsecondary institutions, and to institutions in the
                                                                same algorithmic cluster.
                                                            </p>
                                                        </div>
                                                    </div>
                                                    <div class="row">
                                                        <div class="col-xl-4">
                                                            <div id="carnegie" role="button" tabindex="0" class="box-container">
                                                                <h4 class="heading text-transform-upper">COMPARE AGAINST CARNEGIE PEERS</h4>
                                                                <p class="description">
                                                                    The Carnegie Classification of Institutions of Higher Education® has been a leading framework for recognizing and describing institutional
                                                                    diversity in US higher education for the past 45 years.
                                                                </p>
                                                            </div>
                                                        </div>
                                                        <div class="col-xl-4">
                                                            <div id="world" role="button" tabindex="0" class="box-container">
                                                                <h4 class="heading text-transform-upper">COMPARE AGAINST ALL INSTITUTIONS</h4>
                                                                <p class="description">
                                                                    All four-year US colleges and universities with enrollment greater than 500 students were included in this dataset. Institutions with data
                                                                    availability issues that precluded meaningful comparison were excluded from the interactive.
                                                                </p>
                                                            </div>
                                                        </div>
                                                        <div class="col-xl-4">
                                                            <div id="cluster" role="button" tabindex="0" class="box-container">
                                                                <h4 class="heading text-transform-upper">COMPARE AGAINST INSTITUTIONS WITH SIMILAR ATTRIBUTES</h4>
                                                                <p class="description">
                                                                    To understand how the institutions in this dataset naturally group together, each learner segment was clustered using the k-means
                                                                    algorithm, such that data points in the same cluster are similar and data points in different clusters are farther apart.
                                                                </p>
                                                            </div>
                                                        </div>

                                                                <p class="description-content">
                                                                    Includes the enrollment of underrepresented minority groups, Pell Grant recipients, and 1st-gen students, along with the cost of tuition.

                                                                <p class="description-content">
                                                                    Captures graduation rates, certificate/degree completion rates for non-first-time, full-time, and part-time students, labor market
                                                                    outcomes, social mobility rates, and default rates.
                                                                </p>
                                                                <!-- <div id="Student-outcomes" class="checkBoxContainer" value="Student outcomes"></div> -->
                                                            </div>
                                                        </div>
                                                        <div class="col-xl-3">

                                                                    services, and academic/career counseling services.
                                                                </p>

                    <p class="font18 font-family-open font-weight-bold m-0">Detailed methodology</p>
                </div>

                <div class="accordion-text font-weight-regular" id="accordionThree">
                    <h4 class="font-family-open font16 font-weight-bold" style="margin-bottom: 0rem !important; line-height: 1.5rem; color: #044a71">BACKGROUND</h4>
                    <p class="font-family-open font16" style="margin-top: 0.4rem !important">
                        This interactive serves as a one-stop source for colleges and universities to benchmark how they fare against their peers on different student outcome and equity measures across four distinct student segments identified by Pearson.<a class="blue-text" id="endnotes-7" tabindex="0" onclick="scrollToBottom(event);"><sup>7</sup></a> We have grouped our analysis into four broad categories: access and affordability, student outcomes, flexibility and student services,
                        and other indicators. Provided below are some of the key characteristics for each Pearson student segment that serve as the foundation of our analysis.
                    </p>
                    <p class="font-family-open font16 font-weight-bold" style="color: #707070">Learner segments</p>

                    <ol class="pl-1">
                        <li>
                            <p class="font-family-open font16 pl-2">
                                <span class="font-weight-bold"> Traditional learners:</span> 18–24-year-olds attending brick-and-mortar institutions for the traditional college experience. This segment is less price-sensitive, passionate about learning,
                                prefers in-person instruction, and places a high value on education.
                            </p>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                            <p class="font-family-open font16 pl-2">
                                <span class="font-weight-bold"> Career leaners:</span> These learners place a high value on education, see college as a steppingstone to professional success, and prefer to learn digitally.
                            </p>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                            <p class="font-family-open font16 pl-2">
                                <span class="font-weight-bold"> Reluctant learners:</span> This segment has little passion for learning, favors flexibility, is price-sensitive, and places a low value on higher education. These learners attend college
                                because they have to, not because they want to.
                            </p>
                        </li>
                        <li>
                            <p class="font-family-open font16 pl-2">
                                <span class="font-weight-bold"> Skeptical learners:</span> These learners self-identify as average or below-average students, are very price-sensitive, and favor digital modes of learning over in-person.
                            </p>
                        </li>
                    </ol>
                    <p class="font-family-open font16" style="padding-bottom: 1.5rem">
                        For each learner segment, we identified a set of relevant variables from the following datasets: IPEDS, College Scorecard, Georgetown University’s NPV database, and Raj Chetty’s “Income segregation and intergenerational mobility across colleges in the
                        United States” database available on the Opportunity Insights Data Library.<a class="blue-text" id="endnotes-8" tabindex="0" onclick="scrollToBottom(event);"><sup>8</sup></a>
                                                                            While many of the variables selected are common across learner segments, others are unique to segments given differences in attitudes and preferences (see table a).
                                                                        </p>

                                                                        <h4 class="font-family-open font16 font-weight-bold" style="margin-bottom: 0rem !important; line-height: 1.5rem; color: #044a71; padding-top: 2.5rem">
                                                                            METHODOLOGY AND ASSUMPTIONS
                                                                        </h4>
                                                                        <p class="font-family-open font16" style="margin-top: 0.4rem !important; margin-bottom: 0rem">
                                                                            This dataset includes public, private not-for-profit, and private for-profit four-year postsecondary institutions in the United States.
                                                                        </p>
                                                                        <br>
                                                                        <p class="font-family-open font16">
                                                                            At the outset, a total of 2,882 four-institutions were extracted from IPEDS (note: a small minority of the 2,882 institutions are community colleges that have bachelor’s
                                                                            degree as the highest level of offering). This number was reduced to 1,585 institutions through the following steps:
                                                                        </p>
                                                                        <ol style="padding-bottom: 1.438rem">
                                                                            <li>
                                                                                <p class="font-family-open font16 pl-2">
                                                                                    All institutions with undergraduate enrollment of fewer than 500 students or institutions with blank values were eliminated from this analysis.
                                                                                </p>
                                                                            </li>
                                                                            <li>
                                                                                <p class="font-family-open font16 pl-2">
                                                                                    Similarly, institutions with blank observations for graduation rates for students from underrepresented minority groups (Black or African American and Hispanic
                                                                                    students) and Pell Grant recipients were eliminated, yielding a total of 1,709 institutions.
                                                                                </p>
                                                                            </li>
                                                                            <li>
                                                                                <p class="font-family-open font16 pl-2">
                                                                                    Last, this reduced set of institutions was mapped against Raj Chetty’s social mobility rate (joint probability of parents in the bottom quintile and child in the top
                                                                                    quintile of the income distribution) for the 1991 birth cohort available in the Opportunity Insights Data Library. Institutions that were marked as “colleges with
                                                                                    insufficient data” in the Opportunity Insights’ “Income segregation and intergenerational mobility across colleges in the United States” database, and institutions
                                                                                    that were not part of the database were excluded, yielding a total of 1,585 institutions.
                                                                                </p>
                                                                            </li>
                                                                        </ol>
                                            
                                                                        <h4 class="font-family-open font16 font-weight-bold" style="margin-bottom: 0rem !important; line-height: 1.5rem; color: #044a71">THREE METHODS OF DATA PRESENTATION</h4>
                                                                        <p class="font-family-open font16" style="margin-top: 0.4rem !important; margin-bottom: 0rem">
                                                                            Institutions can compare their performance across variables with their Carnegie peers, with other four-year institutions included in the dataset, and with institutional
                                                                            clusters that emerge algorithmically based on all standardized variables included in this dataset.
                                                                        </p>
                                                                        <br>
                                                                        <p class="font-family-open font16 font-weight-bold" style="margin-bottom: 0rem !important; line-height: 1.5rem; color: #707070">Comparison with Carnegie peers</p>
                                                                        <p class="font-family-open font16" style="margin-top: 0.2rem !important">
                                                                            This approach allows institutions to compare their performance across variables with that of their Carnegie peers. R1 institutions can, for example, compare their values with
                                                                            other doctoral universities with very high research activity and see where they fall on a quartile basis relative to their R1 Carnegie peers. Variables have been standardized
                                                                            using the averages and standard deviation for a specific Carnegie group in order to facilitate apples-to-apples comparison with similar institutions. None of the binary
                                                                            variables were standardized in this analysis.
                                                                        </p>
                                            
                                                                        <p class="font-family-open font16">
                                                                            The number of institutions that fall in a given Carnegie group represents a limitation to this approach. Carnegie groups with fewer than 27 institutions cannot be split into
                                                                            quartiles since the data is not sufficient to carry out calculations.
                                                                        </p>
                                                                        <p class="font-family-open font16" style="padding-bottom: 1.5rem">
                                                                            For Carnegie groups with fewer than 27 institutions, a density curve is not displayed.<br>
                                                                            Moreover, where values were blank in IPEDS, they were either replaced with a value of zero or treated as blank values based on guidance from IPEDS staff (see table b).
                                                                        </p>
                                                                        <p class="font16 font-family-open font-weight-bold font14">Table b. Variables with blank values</p>

                                                                        <br>
                                                                        <p class="font-family-open font16 font-weight-bold" style="margin-bottom: 0rem !important; line-height: 1.5rem; color: #707070">Comparison with other four-year institutions</p>
                                                                        <p class="font-family-open font16" style="margin-top: 0.2rem !important">
                                                                            This approach allows institutions to compare their performance with all other four-year institutions in our sample. To facilitate meaningful comparison, variables were
                                                                            transformed using the methodology presented in table c. To control for demographic variation across states, for example, enrollment variables (with the exception of Pell
                                                                            Grant recipients) were standardized using the averages and standard deviation for the state in which an institution is located. Note that all state-wide averages were
                                                                            calculated using the data included in the sample of 1,585 institutions, rather than the broader set of four-year institutions. These standardization techniques were applied
                                                                            to all four learner segments.
                                                                        </p>
                                                                        <br>
                                                                        <p class="font16 font-family-open font-weight-bold font16" style="margin-top: 0rem !important">Table c. Standardization methods for all variables</p>

Hispanic; American Indian or Alaska Native; and two or more races)</td><td>Standardized by the state in which the institution is located</td><td>Standardized to account for differences in state demographic makeup </td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">2</td><td>Percentage of undergraduate students awarded Pell grants</td><td>Standardized by institution sector, i.e., public, private not-for-profit, or private for-profit. </td><td></td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">3</td><td>Share of first-generation students</td><td>Standardized by institution sector, i.e., public, private not-for-profit, or private for-profit.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">4</td><td>In-state average tuition for full-time undergraduates</td><td>Standardized by the state in which the institution is located</td><td></td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">5</td><td>In-state per-credit hour charge for part-time undergraduates</td><td>Standardized by the state in which the institution is located</td><td></td></tr><tr><td colspan="7" class="category-heading">STUDENT OUTCOMES</td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">6</td><td>Institutional graduation rate</td><td>Standardized by the sample, i.e., using the mean and standard deviation for all 1,585 institutions.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">7</td><td>Graduation rate, Black, non-Hispanic</td><td>Standardized by the sample, i.e., using the mean and standard deviation for all 1,585 institutions.</td><td>Prior to standardizing, we normalized graduation rates by institutional graduation rate. For instance, if the graduation rate for Black, non-Hispanic students at an institution is 40% while the institutional graduation rate is 80%, we divide the graduation rate for Black, non-Hispanic students by the institutional graduation rate before standardizing. This helps assess the gap between the two graduation rates. </td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">8</td><td>Graduation rate, Hispanic</td><td>Standardized by the sample, i.e., using the mean and standard deviation for all 1,585 institutions.</td><td>Graduation rate was normalized by institutional graduation rate prior to standardization. </td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">9</td><td>Pell Grant recipients, overall graduation rate within 150 percent of normal time</td><td>Standardized by the sample, i.e., using the mean and standard deviation for all 1,585 institutions.</td><td>Graduation rate was normalized by institutional graduation rate prior to standardization. </td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">10</td><td>Non-first-time, full-time Pell students receiving an award in 6 years</td><td>Standardized by institution sector, i.e., public, private not-for-profit, or private for-profit.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">11</td><td>Non-first-time, part-time students (total) receiving an award in 8 years</td><td>Standardized by institution sector, i.e., public, private not-for-profit, or private for-profit.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">12</td><td>Raj Chetty’s social mobility rate for 1991-birth-cohort  joint probability of parents in the bottom quintile and child in the top quintile of the income distribution</td><td>Standardized by the sample, i.e., using the mean and standard deviation for all 1,585 institutions.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">13</td><td>Median earnings of students working and not enrolled 10 years after entry</td><td>Standardized by the state in which the institution is located</td><td>Standardized by state because median earnings vary across states. Median earnings for students are benchmarked against institutions in the same state.</td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">14</td><td>10-year net present value of education</td><td>Standardized by institution sector, i.e., public, private not-for-profit, or private for-profit.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">15</td><td>3-year cohort default rate</td><td>Standardized by the sample, i.e., using the mean and standard deviation for all 1,585 institutions.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td colspan="7" class="category-heading">FLEXIBILITY AND SERVICES</td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">16</td><td>Percent of bachelor’s degree programs that can be completed entirely via distance education (aggregated across CIP codes)</td><td>Standardized by institution sector, i.e., public, private not-for-profit, or private for-profit.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">17</td><td>Percentage of degree/certificate-seeking undergraduate students enrolled in some but not all distance education courses</td><td>Standardized by the sample, i.e., using the mean and standard deviation for all 1,585 institutions. </td><td></td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">18</td><td>Percentage of undergraduate students enrolled in some but not all distance education, and those enrolled exclusively in distance education courses </td><td>Standardized by the sample, i.e., using the mean and standard deviation for all 1,585 institutions.</td><td></td></tr><tr><td colspan="7" class="category-heading">OTHER INDICATORS</td></tr><tr><td class="colNum">19</td><td>Full-time instructional staff with faculty status by race/ethnicity (including American Indian or Alaska Native; Black or African American; Hispanic; and two or more races).</td><td>Standardized by the state in which the institution is located</td><td>Standardized to account for differences in state demographic makeup</td></tr></tbody></table></table>

                                                                        </div>
                                                                        <br>
                                                                        <p class="font-family-open font16 font-weight-bold" style="margin-bottom: 0rem !important; line-height: 1.5rem; color: #707070">Cluster analysis</p>
                                                                        <p class="font-family-open font16" style="margin-top: 0.2rem !important">
                                                                            To identify clusters of higher education institutions, we used the k-means clustering algorithm. The algorithm works by allocating institutions into the cluster that minimizes
                                                                            the difference between each member in the cluster and the mean value of that cluster. The algorithm iterates this process and shuffles institutions around until further
                                                                            improvements are not possible. To determine the optimal number of clusters, we used the elbow method that indicates when an additional partition of the data yields a marginal
                                                                            decreasing improvement on the partition. To improve the performance of the model, we also used a dimensionality reduction technique known as principal component analysis
                                                                            (PCA). PCA generates new variables that capture the variation of the original data in a more compact set of new variables. We selected the number of components that preserved
                                                                            85% of the variation of the original data and applied the clustering algorithm to those variables. We repeated this process for each of the four learner segments.
                                                                        </p>
                                                                        <br>
                                                                        <h4 class="font-family-open font16 font-weight-bold" style="margin-bottom: 0.5rem !important; line-height: 1.5rem; color: #044a71">DATA LIMITATIONS</h4>
                                                                        <ol>
                                                                            <li>
                                                                                <p class="font-family-open font16 pl-1">
                                                                                    Raj Chetty’s mobility rate (joint probability of parents in the bottom quintile and child in the top quintile of the income distribution) for 1991 birth cohort
                                                                                </p>
                                                                            </li>
                                                                        </ol>
                                                                        <ul class="pl-6">
                                                                            <li>
                                                                                <p class="font-family-open font16 pl-2">
                                                                                    The mobility rate for the 1991 birth cohort was included in this dataset. Where observations were missing for the 1991 birth cohort, we used the closest available
                                                                                    observation from cohorts spanning 1985–1991. Observations before the 1985 birth cohort were excluded from this analysis.
                                                                                </p>
                                                                            </li>
                                                                            <li>
                                                                                <p class="font-family-open font16 pl-2">
                                                                                    Many institutions have undergone a name change since the time period considered in Raj Chetty’s analysis. In those instances, we manually identified the name change
                                                                                    and used the mobility rate for the previous moniker in the database.
                                                                                </p>
                                                                            </li>
                                                                            <li>
                                                                                <p class="font-family-open font16 pl-2">
                                                                                    Lastly, all institutions labelled “colleges with insufficient data” in Crosswalk from College-Level OPEIDs to Super-OPEID Groups were excluded from this dataset.<a class="blue-text" id="endnotes-9" tabindex="0" onclick="scrollToBottom(event);"><sup>9</sup></a>
                                                                                </p>
                                                                            </li>
                                                                            <li>
                                                                                <p class="font-family-open font16 pl-2">
                                                                                    For additional details regarding the Opportunity Insights’ “Income segregation and intergenerational mobility across colleges in the United States” database,
                                                                                    <u><a class="fontNormal ref-link" tabindex="" role="link" aria-label="additional details regarding the Opportunity Insights" target="_blank" href="https://www2.deloitte.com/us/en/pages/public-sector/solutions/higher-education-services.html">please visit this link</a></u>.
                    </p>
                    </li>
                    </ul>
                    <p class="errormessage font16 font-family-open justify-content-center pt-4 row">
                        <strong>Note: </strong>This analysis was last updated in March 2021. Any updates to the relevant datasets after this date are not reflected in the analysis.
                    </p>
                </div>

    function getCookie(name) 
    {
        var dc = document.cookie;
        var prefix = name + "=";
        var begin = dc.indexOf("; " + prefix);
        if (begin == -1) {
            begin = dc.indexOf(prefix);
            if (begin != 0) return null;
        }
        else
        {
            begin += 2;
            var end = document.cookie.indexOf(";", begin);
            if (end == -1) {
                end = dc.length;
            }
        }
        return unescape(dc.substring(begin + prefix.length, end));
    }

var apiCallFunction = function () {

    var cacheBustDate = new Date();
    var dmdburl = "//api.company-target.com/api/v2/ip.json?key=M65mmM3vaL3giOy4cNEWnOAuvqHh83eUMjTyVFvM&x=" +
        cacheBustDate.getMilliseconds();

        url: dmdburl,
        dataType: "jsonp",
        timeout: 5000,
        success: function (dmdbResult) {
            dmdbDtmData = dmdbResult;

            dmdbDtmData.cache = "false";
            if (typeof dmdbDtmData.company_name !== 'undefined') {

                //Now save to Session Storage

                        }

                } catch (err) {}



            }
            setVariables();
            //Update the Data Layer
            try {
                //console.log("in call");
                dmdDataLayer.dmd = dmdbDtmData;
                //console.log("dmdDataLayer.dmd:",dmdDataLayer.dmd)
                dataLayer.dmd = dmdbDtmData;

            } catch (err) {
                if (err.name == 'ReferenceError') {
                    setTimeout(function () {
                        try {
                            dataLayer.dmd = dmdbDtmData;
                        } catch (error) {
                            if (error.name == 'ReferenceError') {
                                setTimeout(function () {
                                    try {
                                        dataLayer.dmd = dmdbDtmData;
                                    } catch (errorr) {
                                        if (errorr.name == 'ReferenceError') {
                                            setTimeout(function () {
                                                try {
                                                    dataLayer.dmd = dmdbDtmData;
                                                } catch (errorrr) {}
                                            }, 500);
                                        }
                                    }
                                }, 500);
                            }
                        }
                    }, 500);
                }
            }



            //Now save to Session Storage
            try {
                if (guid != null && guid != "" && guid != undefined) {
                    if (cookieCategories.indexOf(",2,") > -1) {
                        window.sessionStorage.setItem("dmdbDtm", JSON.stringify(dmdbDtmData));
                    }
                } else window.sessionStorage.setItem("dmdbDtm", JSON.stringify(dmdbDtmData));


            } catch (err) {}

        }
    });

}
